clustering_scheme.rationale: Both theories center on how people progress through a community while knowledge is transformed and transferred. We therefore separate people pipeline dynamics from knowledge dynamics and from community participation mechanisms, minimizing crossing lines and supporting modular development.

clusters.name: Contributor Pipeline
clusters.theme: Entry, progression, promotion, and attrition of contributors from prospects to core developers.

clusters.name: Knowledge Spiral (SECI)
clusters.theme: Tacit and explicit knowledge creation, conversion, and use supporting learning and progression.

clusters.name: Community Participation (CoP)
clusters.theme: Legitimate peripheral participation, mentoring capacity/load, and social mechanisms that enable engagement and reduce dropout.

layout_hints: Place Contributor Pipeline centrally; it connects most heavily to both other clusters.
Position Knowledge Spiral (SECI) on the left of Pipeline and Community Participation (CoP) on the right to minimize crossing.
Align flows left-to-right from Prospective → New → Experienced → Core within the Pipeline cluster.
Place Project Documentation near Explicit Knowledge Transfer, and Mentoring Capacity near Implicit Knowledge Transfer to shorten cross-cluster links.

theories.name: Communities of Practice (Wenger)
theories.rationale: The model already represents movement from periphery to core (New → Experienced → Core) and mentoring. CoP adds how legitimate peripheral participation and social integration shape learning and retention. Adding participation intensity, mentoring capacity/load, recognition, and explicit onboarding/dropout flows closes key feedbacks, improves behavioral realism (especially attrition), and links community health to pipeline throughput.

variables.name: Onboarding Rate
variables.description: Rate at which Prospective Contributors become New Contributors via legitimate peripheral participation and onboarding mechanisms.

variables.name: Mentoring Capacity
variables.description: Available mentor-hours per period from Core Developer and Experienced Contributors to support newcomers.

variables.name: Mentor Load
variables.description: New Contributors per available mentor (Core + Experienced), capturing overload and its effects.

variables.name: Participation Intensity
variables.description: Average level of newcomer participation in legitimate peripheral activities (triage, reviews, small fixes).

variables.name: Newcomer Dropout Rate
variables.description: Rate at which New Contributors disengage and leave the project.

variables.name: Experienced Contributor Turnover Rate
variables.description: Rate at which Experienced Contributors leave the project.

variables.name: Recognition of Contributions
variables.description: Perceived recognition (e.g., merged PRs, public acknowledgment) that strengthens identity and reduces attrition.

variables.name: colored stock → Prospective Contributors
variables.description: Rename for clarity. Represents the pool of interested individuals who could join as New Contributors.

variables.name: Skill up
variables.description: Clarify direction: outflow from New Contributors and inflow to Experienced Contributors.

variables.name: Promotion Rate
variables.description: Clarify direction: outflow from Experienced Contributors and inflow to Core Developer.

variables.name: Developer's Turnover
variables.description: Clarify direction: outflow from Core Developer to outside the system.

theories.name: Nonaka's SECI Model
theories.rationale: The model includes mentorship (socialization) and a general explicit transfer lever but lacks an explicit knowledge stock and SECI conversion flows. Adding a documentation stock with creation/curation/decay, internalization effectiveness, and practice interactions closes the SECI loop and links knowledge quality to onboarding and learning rates.

variables.name: Project Documentation
variables.description: Accumulated explicit knowledge (docs, guides, ADRs) available to contributors.

variables.name: Documentation Creation Rate
variables.description: Externalization flow: tacit knowledge articulated into new documentation.

variables.name: Documentation Curation Rate
variables.description: Combination flow: consolidation, refactoring, and integration of existing docs.

variables.name: Documentation Decay Rate
variables.description: Loss/outdating of documentation due to codebase changes and obsolescence.

variables.name: Documentation Quality
variables.description: Findability, completeness, and accuracy of Project Documentation.

variables.name: Internalization Effectiveness
variables.description: Effectiveness with which contributors learn from explicit knowledge.

variables.name: Practice Interaction Rate
variables.description: Frequency of social learning interactions (pairing, code reviews, office hours) enabling socialization.
